text: hi everyone
Anthony Pham tanto here Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review atoms for peace among this is the
full-length debut LP of a band fronted
by Thom Yorke sort of a recording
project he has going on with Nigel
Godrich who you also may know as the
producer of Thom Yorke's debut solo LP
the eraser and originally this group had
been formed to perform material from
that album a handful of years ago when
Tom was touring behind it now even
though Atoms for Peace is this new band
it's this new album it's really not all
that far off from other Thom Yorke
related releases for one this album is
very electronic and synthetically
textured in a lot of the same ways that
the eraser was and this LP has an
extremely kind of rhythmic quality too
with a lot of looped beats that pulse a
mechanically but have a ton of detail
and layers to them just like many tracks
off of the King of Limbs and even though
ADM's four-piece is supposed to be a
band with billed musicians such as flea
from the Red Hot Chili Peppers on bass
this does not feel like a live band and
really any way shape or form the sounds
on this LP feel so rigid robotic exact
and meticulous to the point that there
is no way whatsoever we are listening to
live instrumentation which isn't really
the worst thing in the world I guess
what I'm getting at is that atoms for
peace is basically just another Thom
Yorke solo effort under a different flag
now in a way in comparison to the eraser
this LP is maybe even more meticulously
planned out the eraser did have the very
rigid and electronic beats that this
album has but that LP also featured some
guitar just waves of instrumentation
kind of cascading over those beats
whereas this new LP the sense the
guitars they seem to sometimes be as
looped or as rigid as the rhythms
themselves a lot of these beats just
kind of follow in lockstep with the
guitars in the sense a lot like many
spots from the
of limbs that were just more beat
oriented but I actually think that this
new LP has a bit more punch it's got a
bit more clarity it's got a bit more
detail I think in a way I actually kind
of wish that the King of Limbs sounded a
bit more like amok because honestly a
lot of the ballads and a lot of the
softer spots off of that album since I
have listened to it and have ever viewed
it have actually kind of just lost their
flavor for me a little and a lot of the
more beat oriented tracks off of the LP
feel so static to me it's like there's
nothing in terms of a groove or a
progression that moves me amok does
bring a bit more progression and some
really good ballads I think it may end
up kind of getting swept under the rug a
little bit though because it just kind
of feels in a lot of ways like just
typical Thom Yorke very icy very
emotional his nasally wails are all over
the place and underneath these vocals
and just the balance themselves are
these layered and throbbing rhythms that
just go clickety clack clickety clack
and aside from the vocals over these
beats are all of these tones that are
sweet their melancholy sometimes they're
kind of glitchy this LP definitely does
have a sound it has a vibe but still at
the end of the day it ends up kind of
feeling like a collection of tracks
because there's not really a huge
obvious arc or anything like that to the
entire LP what this LP sounds like to me
personally is just further tuning
further alteration of the sound that
Thom Yorke has been chasing after since
the middle of the aughts and I actually
think with with amok he's come closer
than ever to perfecting it the song that
opens up the selfie before your very
eyes there's something about this beat
that to me says gears it says switches
says buttons but there's something about
just Thom Yorke coming in and singing
and I know his voice isn't for everybody
but there's just something about his
voice that that gives these songs just
enough humanity to make them I guess
bearable despite feelings so you know
Bridgette and the song itself
structure-wise is really linear there is
kind of a swell toward the middle of the
track that feels like a chorus with all
these synthesizers all these random
sound effects kind of bumping around
everywhere but the rhythm pretty much
stays exactly the same as it has been
since it kind of kicked in toward the
beginning of the track and that sort of
seems to be a theme on numerous songs
here Thom Yorke is trying to basically
keep these grooves and keep these beats
going and just maintain while changing
things over in giving movement and
giving progression to the song which is
something Radiohead also did on the King
of Limbs but there wasn't enough change
detail or progress to keep the songs
interesting to me the songs on this LP
don't pop they don't really you know
kind of give you a rush they don't shift
gears excitedly when a course kind of
comes in they are much more meditative
they're kind of hypnotic in a way with
how they just continue on and just
change shades very slowly and subtly
like the song unless which is really one
of my favorite tracks on here it's got
this you know a B C sort of structure
with just one part moving into the next
part moving into the next part and just
not really looking back this long slowly
builds into its groove these bad at-bats
since pop in the rhythms eventually get
beefier they get thicker bass eventually
introduces itself along with these weird
vocal samples of Tom's singing popping
up all over the mix kind of encasing my
head in the left and right channels with
just weird
whimpers and moans even lead tracks off
of this LP like default that I reviewed
earlier this year and enjoyed kind of
follow that same pattern another track
that dropped before this LP as well
follows that pattern judge jury and
executioner the acoustics stand out on
this LP a song that I like a lot
I feel like this track has one of the
best beats on the entire LP with the
reverb moans hanging in the background
in this bassline that sounds like like
you're kind of recording this throat
humming sound and it's being looped and
the basses kind of equalized very high
on it so it's very resonant there are a
lot of clicks in this rhythm and just
oddly placed kick drums and I think the
track is one of the prettier vocal
melodies on the entire LP - my only
issue with the song is that I wish it
were
longer it's one thing about this track
and many other songs on here rarely does
this album really kind of come out and
grab me grab my attention or anything
like that however I don't really think
it's boring because I think the songs
and I think the sounds are nice enough
to the point where they actually lure me
in but Thom Yorke is just really not at
a point now where he's writing those
rock songs those very emotive and and
somewhat experimental art rock songs
that people have loved from Radiohead
for so long rather he's kind of taking
his vocals and he's taking a lot of the
same instrumentation and he's trying to
make an electronic song a linearly
structured electronic song he's trying
to apply it all of these familiar
elements to an electronic structure
where you kind of take a groove you take
an idea and basically for a handful of
minutes you sort of not come up with
these several different large lead
contrasted parts in a single track
really it's just one subtle change that
comes on slowly another subtle change
that comes on slowly if there's anything
I really kind of dislike or I am sort of
disappointed with in regards to this LP
there are some nice synthesizers and
vocals on this thing for sure that are
treated and some just heavy wet effects
just cavernous cascading vocals just
layering on top of each other in a
really nice way on some of these songs
but the beats feel so freakin dry and
flat sometimes it's like a burnt piece
of Turkey between two pieces of toast
the sounds can feel really kind of plain
if you listen to this entire 40-minute
LP from beginning to end sure it does
have a style and it does have an
approach but there could be a little bit
more texture in some of these beats to
make them a little bit more worth
sinking your teeth into the sounds of
the rhythms are just mysteriously
mysteriously untreated like there was a
severe lack of post-production
in the making of these songs no doubt
there are some cool songs and melodies
on this LP especially nasty grooves like
on the song stuck together pieces
there's some detailed instrumentation
and Thom Yorke has improved when it
comes to taking this rock instrument
and applying it to an electronic
structure what this album really could
have needed were maybe just some tracks
of a different energy level a different
flavor some different sounds and you
know the the sonic experimentation that
explorative edge that albums like a
music and kid a have I'm actually
feeling a strong six to a lay seven on
this LP I enjoyed it quite a bit but if
you've given it a listen what did you
think
did you love it did you hate it why what
should i review next and yeah that's it
Anthony Fantana Atoms for Peace forever
[Music]
